docs.abstract: Political news from today's Times and around the Web, plus a look at the president's weekly address.
docs.snippet: Political news from today's Times and around the Web, plus a look at the president's weekly address.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act has prevailed in the Supreme Court, but two years after its approval, the public is no happier with the law than it was then.

headline.seo: Health Care Overhaul Is Still No Hit With Public
headline.main: For Obama, a Signature Issue That the Public Never Embraced Looms Large
headline.print_headline: For Obama, a Signature Issue That the Public Never Embraced Looms Large

docs.abstract: American public is no happier with the health care reform law two years after its passage than it was when it was signed by Pres Obama; although the law has been upheld by the Supreme Court, many Democrats are frustrated by Obama's lack of follow-through and his failure to convince Americans of the merits of the law; Obama and his allies have made it clear that they will try to shift the national conversation back to the economy, the main electoral battleground.
docs.snippet: The Affordable Care Act has prevailed in the Supreme Court, but two years after its approval, the public is no happier with the law than it was then.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The political upshot, strategists said, could be a wash. Much depends on how each side handles the message wars in the aftermath of the ruling.

headline.seo: Campaigns Try to Define Tax Issue in Supreme Court’s Health Care Ruling
headline.main: Tax or Penalty? Both Campaigns Are Quick to Define Court’s Health Care Ruling
headline.print_headline: Tax or Penalty? Both Campaigns Are Quick to Define Court’s Health Care Ruling

docs.abstract: Supreme Court ruling on the health care reform law has put the topic of taxes front and center for the 2012 campaign, as both the Obama and Romney campaigns scramble to define the issue to their advantage; Pres Obama's supporters insist the law's penalty for people who do not buy insurance is not a tax, while Republicans rush to call it a tax.
docs.snippet: The political upshot, strategists said, could be a wash. Much depends on how each side handles the message wars in the aftermath of the ruling.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican officials in more than a half-dozen states considered an option granted in the Supreme Court’s decision on the health care law.

headline.seo: Some States Reluctant Over Medicaid Expansion
headline.main: Reluctance in Some States Over Medicaid Expansion
headline.print_headline: Reluctance in Some States Over Medicaid Expansion

docs.abstract: Republican officials in more than a half-dozen states say they oppose or have serious doubts about expanding Medicaid, even though the federal government would pick up all the costs in the first few years and at least 90 percent of the expenses after that; the Supreme Court ruled that states do not have to expand Medicaid as Congress had intended, leaving a huge question mark over the law’s mechanism for providing coverage to 17 million of the poorest people.
docs.snippet: Republican officials in more than a half-dozen states considered an option granted in the Supreme Court’s decision on the health care law.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and MICHAEL COOPER

docs.lead_paragraph: A day after the Supreme Court upheld most of the health care law, a blend of wariness, optimism and confusion spread amongst the uninsured of Texas.

headline.seo: For Uninsured in Texas, Ruling Adds Uncertainty
headline.main: For Uninsured in Texas, Supreme Court Ruling Adds to Uncertainty
headline.print_headline: For Uninsured in Texas, Supreme Court Ruling Adds to Uncertainty

docs.abstract: Supreme Court decision upholding the health care reform law adds another element of uncertainty to the uninsured residents of Texas, which has the highest uninsured rate of any state, because of its restriction of the Medicaid expansion; many Texans who would have been eligible for Medicaid under the expansion remain in a state of limbo.
docs.snippet: A day after the Supreme Court upheld most of the health care law, a blend of wariness, optimism and confusion spread amongst the uninsured of Texas.

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican-led states should stop stalling on implementing health care reform now that it is here to stay.

headline.seo: It’s Time to Set Up Health Insurance Exchanges
headline.main: It’s Time to Set Up Exchanges
headline.print_headline: It’s Time to Set Up Exchanges

docs.abstract: Editorial calls on Republican-led states to stop stalling on implementing aspects of the health care reform law, particularly the creation of state insurance policy exchanges, now that the Supreme Court has ruled the law constitutional.
docs.snippet: Republican-led states should stop stalling on implementing health care reform now that it is here to stay.

keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The decision on health care reform has Republicans fuming. But, make no mistake, the ruling was a victory for the president and the nation.
docs.abstract: Charles M Blow Op-Ed column contends that the Supreme Court decision upholding the health care reform law is a victory for both Pres Obama and the nation; disputes Republican claims that a majority of Americans still want the law repealed.
docs.snippet: The decision on health care reform has Republicans fuming. But, make no mistake, the ruling was a victory for the president and the nation.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Even if Republicans were to win the White House and a narrow Senate majority, undoing the major benefits and policies of the law would require the unlikely assent of Senate Democrats.

headline.main: For Opponents of Health Care Law, No Easy Road to Repeal
headline.print_headline: Politics and Popular Provisions Make Health Law Hard to Erase

docs.abstract: Congressional Republicans vow to use their legislative muscle to repeal the Affordable Care Act, despite the Supreme Court's ruling to uphold it; attacking the law by stripping away its layers of taxes, fees and subsidies is not the same, however, as dismantling it; undoing the major benefits and policies of the law would require the acquiescence of Senate Democrats, which is highly unlikely.
docs.snippet: Even if Republicans were to win the White House and a narrow Senate majority, undoing the major benefits and policies of the law would require the unlikely assent of Senate Democrats.
